image.altText: A man with cap and white beard at a racing stables leans on a fence.

items.synopsis: Tasracing's leading greyhound trainer of the year, Anthony Bullock, is handed a lifetime disqualification from the sport over the use of an animal part for baiting. Mr Bullock had denied the allegation.

title.children: Lifetime ban for Tasmania's leading greyhound trainer after baiting inquiry

image.altText: A woman is choosing fruits at supermarket.

items.synopsis: Consumer prices rose 1.2 per cent in the September quarter, slightly above economist forecasts and increasing the risks of another Reserve Bank interest rate rise.

title.children: Inflation stronger than expected and now has banks and traders pricing in a November rate rise

image.altText: A tree lies across a silver car.

items.synopsis: Winds of up to 159kph batter Tasmania overnight and this morning, causing damage to houses, cars and power infrastructure. They also caused delays to this year's Royal Hobart Show dog competition.

title.children: Severe winds lash Tasmania, damage Hobart Show pavilion — but show opening still on track

image.altText: A man inspects as Palestinians search for casualties at the site of an Israeli strike on a house.

items.synopsis: Israel's total siege of the Gaza Strip has displaced 1.4 million Palestinians and the health authority is warning of disease outbreaks amid the overcrowding.

title.children: Gaza health ministry says at least 700 Palestinians killed overnight, Israel claims dozens of militants killed in strikes

image.altText: RAAF C-17 Globemaster brings supplies for Cyclone Lam hit Elcho Island

items.synopsis: The federal government will deploy extra troops and aircraft to the Middle East over concerns for the "volatile security situation" as it calls for a "humanitarian pause" in the Israel-Gaza conflict.

title.children: Australian troops and aircraft deployed to Middle East, Wong calls for 'humanitarian pause' in Israel-Gaza conflict

image.altText: A plate with an ornate menu sits on a table with floral decorations and gold cutlery

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese and his partner will be treated to an exquisite meal when they sit down as guests of honour at a White House state dinner tomorrow, but the event has been significantly toned down in light of the Israel-Gaza war.

title.children: Albanese's date with Biden will feature a star-studded guest list, but it'll be a scaled-down affair

image.altText: A blond and white echidna walks along a rocky surface.

items.synopsis: Until he saw one up close, Zach didn't know echidnas could be white. He didn't realise just how lucky he was to spot this rare animal in Tasmania's wilderness.

title.children: 'Super rare, beautiful animal': White echidna spotted near Tasmania's Cradle Mountain

image.altText: A plane wing extends out over the surface of Antarctica

items.synopsis: Using satellite data, researchers uncover an ancient river system hidden for millions of years beneath the East Antarctic Ice Sheet.

title.children: 'Frozen in time': Ancient landscape beneath Antarctica revealed

image.altText: Several people walking past a large ship, as the Sydney Harbour Bridge can be seen in the background

items.synopsis: The Federal Court finds Carnival Australia was negligent and engaged in misleading representations over the voyage in 2020, which led to 600 people being infected with COVID-19.

title.children: Ruby Princess passengers win lawsuit over COVID outbreak on ill-fated voyage

image.altText: burned out buildings in the bush seen from above

items.synopsis: At least five structures have been destroyed and authorities fear there are more losses to come as fires continue to burn in hot, dry conditions today and tomorrow.

title.children: One person dead as Queensland bushfires threaten properties in tinderbox conditions

image.altText: A man in a suit, seen from behind, looks at the ASX share price boards.

items.synopsis: The ASX has opened higher at the start of trade after US corporate earnings generally beat expectations, while the ABS says fuel, electricity and rents influenced a 1.2 per cent rise in inflation. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens higher, ABS says higher fuel prices behind jump in inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Today's inflation figures were enough for ANZ to shift its thinking on the RBA's rates meeting next month, saying it now expects the cash rate to increase by 0.25 percentage points, taking the official rate to 4.35%. Given the RBA's "hawkish rhetoric over the past two weeks" and the "uncomfortably high" September quarter inflation data, ANZ says it's expecting the cash rate to reach its highest level since November 2011 — but noted the hike wasn't certain. "The RBA has also highlighted risks of inflation expectations becoming embedded given ongoing shocks to energy prices, with consumers’ inflation expectations typically being quite responsive to petrol prices," ANZ's head of economics Adam Boyton wrote. "While an additional interest rate increase will put further pressure on already strained finances across some households, the RBA’s most recent Financial Stability Review observed that households and businesses in Australia have, overall, coped reasonably well with the [4 percentage point] cash rate hikes so far. "Having said that, a rate hike in November is not certain. Major inputs into the RBA’s longer-term inflation forecast are unlikely to have changed materially. "Wages growth has generally undershot the RBA's expectations over this cycle, while the likely increase in productivity in Q3 should provide some comfort to the Bank that a reversion to the pre-COVID trend is plausible. That is, the longer-term inflation forecasts could well be unaffected by today's data. "As a result, a decision to increase rates in November could well be a response to the risk that inflation might not return to target within a reasonable timeframe. A risk highlighted by the resilience of inflation in the [September inflation data]."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ expects RBA to increase cash rate to 4.35pc in November

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a positive start to Wednesday trade for the ASX, but its early morning gains have taken a substantial hit in the wake of inflation data coming in higher than economists had expected. As of 12:10pm AEDT, the ASX 200 is down -0.2% to 6,844 points. Investors are now weighing up the possibility of a November rate hike by the RBA, with the market currently forecasting a 60.6% chance of an increase next month. Before the inflation data was released, that forecasted rate hike probability was sitting at just 35%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX loses ground after inflation figures exceed expectations

children.content: It was a positive start to Wednesday trade for the ASX, but its early morning gains have taken a substantial hit in the wake of inflation data coming in higher than economists had expected.
As of 12:10pm AEDT, the ASX 200 is down
-0.2% to 6,844 points
Investors are now weighing up the possibility of a November rate hike by the RBA, with the
market currently forecasting a 60.6% chance of an increase
next month.
Before the inflation data was released, that forecasted rate hike probability was sitting at just 35%.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to AMP's chief deputy economist Diana Mousina, who has been discussing the inflation data with finance presenter Alicia Barry on News Channel. She says the quarterly 1.2% inflation increase means we're in a "grey zone" but it isn't enough to say for certain whether it will prompt the RBA to lift the cash rate on November 7. "A key number I was looking for was that underlying measure of inflation, and coming out of 1.2% over the quarter, I think that there is a complete 50-50 coin toss as to whether the RBA will hike rates in November because it is a bit of a grey area," she said. "I was thinking if the number was closer to 1.3% then the Reserve Bank would probably hike, but 1.2% probably does still mean that inflation projections over the next two years are still intact. "They are forecasting inflation to only come down from its target band of 2.5% by 2025, so I think a 1.2% underlying inflation figure still does keep that in line, but it probably will concern them because we have seen that underlying inflation has ticked up from last quarter at 0.9% and it has now got up to 1.2%. "When I look at the components in today's data there are still signs that in services you are still seeing sticky prices, which is what [RBA] governor Bullock has been talking about the past few times she has spoken in recent weeks."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The chance of a rate rise by the RBA next month is a 'complete 50-50 coin toss'

children.content: That's according to
AMP's chief deputy economist Diana Mousina
, who has been discussing the inflation data with
finance presenter Alicia Barry
on News Channel.
She says the quarterly 1.2% inflation increase means we're in a "grey zone" but it isn't enough to say for certain whether it will prompt the RBA to lift the cash rate on November 7.
"A key number I was looking for was that underlying measure of inflation, and coming out of 1.2% over the quarter,
I think that there is a complete 50-50 coin toss as to whether the RBA will hike rates in November
because it is a bit of a grey area," she said.
"I was thinking if the number was closer to 1.3% then the Reserve Bank would probably hike, but 1.2% probably does still mean that
inflation projections over the next two years are still intact
"They are forecasting inflation to only come down from its target band of 2.5% by 2025, so I think a 1.2% underlying inflation figure still does keep that in line, but it
probably will concern them because we have seen that underlying inflation has ticked up
from last quarter at 0.9% and it has now got up to 1.2%.
"When I look at the components in today's data there are still signs that in services you are
still seeing sticky prices
, which is what [RBA] governor Bullock has been talking about the past few times she has spoken in recent weeks."

props.alt: A woman sitting in an office chair against a blank white wall with news tickers overlaying the bottom explaining the inflation data result.

children.content: AMP's Diana Mousina says it's a complete coin toss if the RBA will raise rates next month.
(ABC News)

image.altText: Lee Sedol during the Google DeepMind challenge match

items.synopsis: A board game contest between human and machine in 2016 marked the birth of modern AI. This is the moment the world changed forever.

title.children: 'The most shocking thing I've ever seen': How one move in an ancient board game changed our view of AI

image.altText: A large crowd gathered outside the Opera House

items.synopsis: Documents produced in parliament yesterday revealed senior NSW police held concerns a pro-Palestinian protest at the Opera House earlier in the month could "escalate current tensions".

title.children: 'I made an error': NSW premier responds to senior police concerns over Sydney Opera House protest

image.altText: man in front of a brick wall looking into the camera

items.synopsis: Paedophile teacher Grahame Harold Steele died a decade ago and was never criminally prosecuted. An inquiry has allowed one of his victims, Grant Holland, to finally feel heard for the first time.

title.children: A 'hopeless' police sting couldn't bring down Grant's abuser. 48 years later, he's finding validation

image.altText: A middle-aged Australian woman of Chinese heritage smiles in front of a dark-curtained background.

items.synopsis: "While you are clothed and fed, you are warm and you are safe — the safest you'll ever be — you are undergoing, I think, the utmost pain emotionally, psychologically," she tells 7.30.

title.children: 'A sophisticated form of torture': Australian journalist Cheng Lei details detention ordeal

image.altText: A man near a door looking at the camera

items.synopsis: The West Bank doesn't usually get a mention in conversations about the world's hottest property markets, but this home is sought after for specific reasons.

title.children: Mohammed says he's been offered $100m for his home. This is why he'll never leave

image.altText: Zoe holding a folder. Pauline and Cobie holding a dog. Picture of defect in home.

items.synopsis: Would-be home owners are unable to finish their homes and can't claw back their deposits after a builder linked to a national franchise construction company went into liquidation.

title.children: Customers' homes riddled with defects after building franchise goes into liquidation

image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Police investigating the fatal shooting of Gavin Preston in the Melbourne suburb of Keilor last month have charged a 22-year-old man with murder, following his arrest in New South Wales.

title.children: Man charged with murder over cafe shooting of Melbourne gangland figure Gavin Preston

image.altText: Joseph David Emerson standing behind protective glass in court as another man in a suit stands to the side of him

items.synopsis: A US commercial airline pilot who tried to cut engines mid-flight while he was riding in an extra cockpit seat told police he had recently taken psychedelic mushrooms as his mental health worsened, documents say.

title.children: 'I'm not OK': Off-duty pilot who tried to cut engines mid-flight told police he experimented with mushrooms

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: Condon stolen ute

items.synopsis: A 27-year-old motorbike rider has been taken to hospital after he was allegedly hit by a teenage driver in a stolen ute.

title.children: Teens bailed, motorcyclist taken to hospital after stolen ute crash in Queensland

image.altText: composit image of donald trump frowning in court and michael cohen waving as he walks outside

items.synopsis: It's a fraught courtroom showdown five years in the making — between Mr Trump and the now-disbarred lawyer who once pledged to "take a bullet" for him.

title.children: Former lawyer testifies he boosted value of Trump assets to 'whatever number' he was told

image.altText: A young white boy with intellectual disability. He is in a classroom and being spoken to by a teacher's aide

items.synopsis: Debate has erupted again over the future of special schools following the disability royal commission's final report. Here's why the issue is so complex and personal.

title.children: 'Parents are outraged': Why closing special schools is such a complex topic

image.altText: Sun setting over Indian Ocean

title.children: 'Not a great outlook' for Queenslanders as temperatures soar, bureau says

image.altText: Woman wearing blue shirt stands against a wall with her garden in the background

items.synopsis: Cattle prices have collapsed as producers rush to sell stock before the big dry sets in. But at the supermarket, you wouldn't know it.

title.children: Elke is frustrated you're paying so much for beef when she can't extract a fair price for her cattle

image.altText: Against a yellow peeling paint background, a person with short fair hair wears industrial sized glasses and a white face mask.

items.synopsis: From coal to asbestos, there's a long and deadly history of dust in Australia. And some are arguing that the lessons of the past aren't being applied today.

title.children: Thousands of needless deaths from asbestos taught Australia tough lessons. Have they been forgotten?

image.altText: A balding man in a jacket and tie stands at a media microphone

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory opposition has been accused of "putting the cart before the horse" as it announces an election pitch to scrap treaty plans and push for council changes.

title.children: NT's treaty in jeopardy, as opposition locks in 'disappointing' stance

image.altText: Portrait of a woman in her late sixties who is in front of a book case. She has short hair and light blue eyes.

items.synopsis: As she retires, the High Court chief justice reflects on her unconventional journey to the top of the legal profession.

title.children: 'A policy of not briefing women': How Susan Kiefel overcame bias to become our first female chief justice

image.altText: A military helicopter lands in bushland, kicking up clouds of dust.

items.synopsis: A broken engine component has been identified as the "primary" cause of an Army helicopter accident in March, but investigators are still working to determine the precise reasons for a crash that killed four soldiers off the Queensland coast several months later.

title.children: Investigations rule out links between fatal Queensland army chopper crash and earlier Jervis Bay incident

title.children: Two of the most iconic teams in rugby are set to meet in another historic final
